alert.note: Alert for Koochiching (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Duluth (Northeast Minnesota and Northern Wisconsin)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued June 15 at 2:05PM CDT until June 19 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Duluth
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM CDT MONDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues. Namakan and Rainy Lake have both surpassed levels set during the 2014 peak levels with Rainy Lake now above the 1950 record peak as well. * WHERE...Portions of north central Minnesota and northeast Minnesota, including the following counties, in north central Minnesota, Koochiching. In northeast Minnesota, St. Louis. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...Flooding of lakes, rivers, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Several structures are flooded and some sand bagging operations are continuing. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 145 PM CDT, emergency management reported ongoing extensive flooding. - The level of Namakan Lake is expected to fall by 11 to 13 inches between June 15th and June 22nd. On Wednesday the level of Rainy Lake held steady or rose slightly after heavy rain. The level of Rainy Lake is expected to fall by 2 to 3 inches between June 15th and June 22nd. The decline in all levels and flows is expected to continue beyond the seven day period. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... International Falls, Kabetogama, Crane Lake, Kabetogama Lake, Voyageurs National Park, Rainy Lake East, Rainy Lake West, northwestern Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, Ranier, Ray, Island View, Ericksburg and Sand Point Lake. - For more information about the Rainy Lake Basin flooding visit, https://www.weather.gov/dlh/RainyRiverBasin
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Once levels have peaked, it will take a matter of weeks to a month for levels to decline to near normal summer levels. Additional rainfall will prolong the time it takes for levels to recede.
